ratings.comment: Really liked this guy. Eccentric. Someone said he looks like a cross between Steven Spielberg and Michael Moore. Fair exams and grading.

He is definitely an eccentric genius.  He genuinely seems interested in making you learn something and not just get escorting you to an "A".  This is one of those classes where it is DIRELY important to do the book problems.  He is generally approachable, but don't be scared off by the ugg boot wearing exterior.

Bauman is a genius and it shows, but he is very good at giving examples that are helpful and fairly easy to understand.  Math 222 is a difficult class to begin with but he makes it so much better with his funny comments and extreme knowledge on the subject.

Without Bauman I would not have passed calc.  I had him for both calc 221 and 222.  If you aren't into learning all the theories and proofs of the problems Bauman is your guy.  He's not over your head like most math professors at Madison and does alot of examples in class. Very very helpful, nice guy, fair grader. Best math teacher ive had!

Take Bauman if you need calc 222. Exams are fair, lectures are clear and helpful, and he lets you use a notecard on all exams. I haven't heard of other profs allowing them for all exams. Material can be tough so go to TA or office hours for help

This class was awful, poorly designed and conceived on all levels. I think the grade should not be based just on exams. It's not that kind of material, and doing so is unfair to students. Bauman is nice enough, but his lecturing style covers too much material without enough depth to really teach students how to solve different types of problems.

Bauman is a great guy. Super-nice and always willing to help out. 222 is probably one of the hardest courses on campus content-wise, and depending on your TA, can make or break your grade. My TA wasn't great but I got progressively better because I attended the (non-mandatory) lectures. Great teacher, fair exams and the final was pretty fair too.
Bauman is a nice old man.  I rarely understood his lectures when I was there but then after discussion they would start to click.

Quite the interesting professor. Class may scare you because the content isn't meant to be easy. He teaches fairly well but the exams can be tricky because he'll throw things on there that you may not remember how to do (tricky integrals and trig stuff). He's a really nice old guy who laughs in a funny way. Take his class but you'll be working hard
What a great guy! You have love his duck sweater and charming personality.

Bauman is a great lecturer and very understandable!  It's so funny to watch him become really excited about the math he's doing!  His exams are fair, and he's really helpful in office hours.  A great professor for a hard course!
This professor really helped me understand the difficult material.  If you do the homework, ask questions and attend lecture you'll do just fine.
Lecture was basically useless...he did more confusing than teaching.  Book was the best source of info

Grades and the tests are extremely fair, make sure you study previous exams on the math library website. Lectures are very useful, spends a lot of time using proofs, but also does a lot of examples so make sure you go to lecture. I understood Calc rather than just 'did' it because of him. Probably my favorite professor in the math department.

If you are not a math major, this is the class for you.  First, if at first you don't understand something, don't panic, Bauman will give plenty of examples.  Second, he allows notecard(s) on exams.  Homework is not mandatory, but can boost your grade.  I bombed the final and still managed an A/B.  He's also a nice guy and lectures are worthwhile

Likes to show proofs, but doesn't really just show how to do the problem.  Pretty unclear as to where he gets many of the the things he writes.  Previous calc experience is an absolute necessity if you plan to understand anything whatsoever...
Good lecturer, doesnt get off task and will make time to see his students. Tests are fair and truly reflect the homework.
